{
 "cells": [
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "4df04cd5",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%% md\n"
    }
   },
   "source": [
    "# Directional semivariograms\n",
    "\n",
    "## Table of Contents:\n",
    "\n",
    "1. Read point data,\n",
    "2. Create directional and isotropic semivariograms,\n",
    "3. Compare semivariograms,\n",
    "4. Compare triangular vs elliptical neighbors selection methods.\n",
    "\n",
    "## Level: Basic\n",
    "\n",
    "## Changelog\n",
    "\n",
    "| Date | Change description | Author |\n",
    "|------|--------------------|--------|\n",
    "| 2022-10-17 | Bug update: directions are calculated in a valid way. New feature: added comparison between elliptical and triangular neighbors selection | @SimonMolinsky |\n",
    "| 2022-09-22 | The first version of tutorial | @SimonMolinsky |\n",
    "\n",
    "## Introduction\n",
    "\n",
    "In this tutorial, we will learn about directional semivariograms, how to set the angle of `direction` and what's the `tolerance` parameter. We compare two neighbor selection methods: **triangular** that is fast and **elliptical** that is accurate.\n",
    "\n",
    "### A directional proces\n",
    "\n",
    "Not every spatial process may be described by isotropic semivariograms. Sometimes we see a specific trend in one direction (N-S, W-E, or NE-SW, NW-SE). A well performed analysis includes directions, that's why we will learn how to write a code in `pyinterpolate` that retrieves the directional variogram.\n",
    "\n",
    "We use the air pollution data downloaded with the package.\n",
    "\n",
    "> **Note**: if you you are a machine learning enthusiast it will be easier for you to understand **direction** as an additional feature used to model semivariance.\n",
    "\n",
    "## Import packages"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 1,
   "id": "5a96356b",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%%\n"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "import geopandas as gpd\n",
    "import numpy as np\n",
    "import pandas as pd\n",
    "\n",
    "import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n",
    "\n",
    "# IO - read text\n",
    "from pyinterpolate import download_air_quality_poland\n",
    "# Experimental variogram\n",
    "from pyinterpolate import build_experimental_variogram\n",
    "# Theoretical Variogram\n",
    "from pyinterpolate import TheoreticalVariogram, build_theoretical_variogram"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "f872c325",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%% md\n"
    }
   },
   "source": [
    "## 1) Read and show point data"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 2,
   "id": "6fda5c3b",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%%\n"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "DATASET = 'PM2.5'\n",
    "\n",
    "# This block is commented intentionally.\n",
    "# You may uncomment the last line and download a new dataset, but there is a high chance that you'll obtain\n",
    "# a different results! To be sure, that results are the same, use data stored in the\n",
    "# 'samples/directional_variogram_PM25_20220922.csv' file. See next cell.\n",
    "\n",
    "# ds = download_air_quality_poland(DATASET)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 3,
   "id": "ac2f1fd8",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%%\n"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "text/html": [
       "<div>\n",
       "<style scoped>\n",
       "    .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type {\n",
       "        vertical-align: middle;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "\n",
       "    .dataframe tbody tr th {\n",
       "        vertical-align: top;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "\n",
       "    .dataframe thead th {\n",
       "        text-align: right;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "</style>\n",
       "<table border=\"1\" class=\"dataframe\">\n",
       "  <thead>\n",
       "    <tr style=\"text-align: right;\">\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "      <th>y</th>\n",
       "      <th>x</th>\n",
       "      <th>PM2.5</th>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>station_id</th>\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "  </thead>\n",
       "  <tbody>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>659</th>\n",
       "      <td>50.529892</td>\n",
       "      <td>22.112467</td>\n",
       "      <td>7.12765</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>736</th>\n",
       "      <td>54.380279</td>\n",
       "      <td>18.620274</td>\n",
       "      <td>4.66432</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>861</th>\n",
       "      <td>54.167847</td>\n",
       "      <td>19.410942</td>\n",
       "      <td>3.00739</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>266</th>\n",
       "      <td>51.259431</td>\n",
       "      <td>22.569133</td>\n",
       "      <td>7.10000</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>355</th>\n",
       "      <td>51.856692</td>\n",
       "      <td>19.421231</td>\n",
       "      <td>2.00000</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "  </tbody>\n",
       "</table>\n",
       "</div>"
      ],
      "text/plain": [
       "                    y          x    PM2.5\n",
       "station_id                               \n",
       "659         50.529892  22.112467  7.12765\n",
       "736         54.380279  18.620274  4.66432\n",
       "861         54.167847  19.410942  3.00739\n",
       "266         51.259431  22.569133  7.10000\n",
       "355         51.856692  19.421231  2.00000"
      ]
     },
     "execution_count": 3,
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "execute_result"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "ds = pd.read_csv('samples/directional_variogram_PM25_20220922.csv', index_col='station_id')\n",
    "ds.head()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 4,
   "id": "fa162c14",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%%\n"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "def df2gdf(df, lon_col='x', lat_col='y', epsg=4326, crs=None):\n",
    "    \"\"\"\n",
    "    Function transforms DataFrame into GeoDataFrame.\n",
    "    \n",
    "    Parameters\n",
    "    ----------\n",
    "    df : pandas DataFrame\n",
    "    \n",
    "    lon_col : str, default = 'x'\n",
    "        Longitude column name.\n",
    "        \n",
    "    lat_col : str, default = 'y'\n",
    "        Latitude column name.\n",
    "        \n",
    "    epsg : Union[int, str], default = 4326\n",
    "        EPSG number of projection.\n",
    "        \n",
    "    crs : str, default = None\n",
    "        Coordinate Reference System of data.\n",
    "        \n",
    "    Returns\n",
    "    -------\n",
    "    gdf : GeoPandas GeoDataFrame\n",
    "        GeoDataFrame with set geometry column ('geometry'), CRS, and all columns from the passed DataFrame.\n",
    "    \n",
    "    \"\"\"\n",
    "    \n",
    "    gdf = gpd.GeoDataFrame(df)\n",
    "    gdf['geometry'] = gpd.points_from_xy(x=df[lon_col], y=df[lat_col])\n",
    "    gdf.geometry = gdf['geometry']\n",
    "    \n",
    "    if crs is None:\n",
    "        gdf.set_crs(epsg=epsg, inplace=True)\n",
    "    else:\n",
    "        gdf.set_crs(crs=crs, inplace=True)\n",
    "        \n",
    "    return gdf"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 5,
   "id": "7691bfbf",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%%\n"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "text/html": [
       "<div>\n",
       "<style scoped>\n",
       "    .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type {\n",
       "        vertical-align: middle;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "\n",
       "    .dataframe tbody tr th {\n",
       "        vertical-align: top;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "\n",
       "    .dataframe thead th {\n",
       "        text-align: right;\n",
       "    }\n",
       "</style>\n",
       "<table border=\"1\" class=\"dataframe\">\n",
       "  <thead>\n",
       "    <tr style=\"text-align: right;\">\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "      <th>y</th>\n",
       "      <th>x</th>\n",
       "      <th>PM2.5</th>\n",
       "      <th>geometry</th>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>station_id</th>\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "      <th></th>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "  </thead>\n",
       "  <tbody>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>659</th>\n",
       "      <td>50.529892</td>\n",
       "      <td>22.112467</td>\n",
       "      <td>7.12765</td>\n",
       "      <td>POINT (22.11247 50.52989)</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>736</th>\n",
       "      <td>54.380279</td>\n",
       "      <td>18.620274</td>\n",
       "      <td>4.66432</td>\n",
       "      <td>POINT (18.62027 54.38028)</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>861</th>\n",
       "      <td>54.167847</td>\n",
       "      <td>19.410942</td>\n",
       "      <td>3.00739</td>\n",
       "      <td>POINT (19.41094 54.16785)</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>266</th>\n",
       "      <td>51.259431</td>\n",
       "      <td>22.569133</td>\n",
       "      <td>7.10000</td>\n",
       "      <td>POINT (22.56913 51.25943)</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "    <tr>\n",
       "      <th>355</th>\n",
       "      <td>51.856692</td>\n",
       "      <td>19.421231</td>\n",
       "      <td>2.00000</td>\n",
       "      <td>POINT (19.42123 51.85669)</td>\n",
       "    </tr>\n",
       "  </tbody>\n",
       "</table>\n",
       "</div>"
      ],
      "text/plain": [
       "                    y          x    PM2.5                   geometry\n",
       "station_id                                                          \n",
       "659         50.529892  22.112467  7.12765  POINT (22.11247 50.52989)\n",
       "736         54.380279  18.620274  4.66432  POINT (18.62027 54.38028)\n",
       "861         54.167847  19.410942  3.00739  POINT (19.41094 54.16785)\n",
       "266         51.259431  22.569133  7.10000  POINT (22.56913 51.25943)\n",
       "355         51.856692  19.421231  2.00000  POINT (19.42123 51.85669)"
      ]
     },
     "execution_count": 5,
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "execute_result"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "gds = df2gdf(ds)\n",
    "gds.head()"
   ]
  },

       "geometry    False\n",
       "dtype: bool"
      ]
     },
     "execution_count": 6,
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "execute_result"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "gds.isna().any()"
   ]
  },

    "gds = gds.dropna(axis=0)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",

   "id": "085f46b8",
   "metadata": {

     "data": {
      "text/plain": [
       "Text(0.5, 1.0, 'PM2.5 concentrations in Poland')"
      ]
     },
     "execution_count": 8,
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "execute_result"
    },
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "\n",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 1000x1000 with 2 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "gds = gds.to_crs(epsg=2180)\n",
    "gds.plot(figsize=(10, 10), column=DATASET, legend=True, markersize=20, alpha=0.7)\n",
    "plt.title('PM2.5 concentrations in Poland')"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "6004d719",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%% md\n"
    }
   },
   "source": [
    "## 2) Create the experimental semivariogram\n",
    "\n",
    "If we recall the tutorial `Semivariogram Estimation`, there are three main parameters to set for the `build_experimental_variogram()` function:\n",
    "\n",
    "1. `input_array`: `numpy array` with coordinates and observed values, for example `[[0, 0, 10], [0, 1, 20]]`,\n",
    "2. `step_size`: we must divide our area of analysis into discrete **lags**. **Lags** are intervals (usually circular) within which we check if the point has a neighbor. For example, if we look into the lag `500`, then we are going to compare one point with other points in a distance `(0, 1000]` from this point,\n",
    "3. `max_range`: it is a tricky one, and it is hard to guess it at the first try. This parameter represents the possible **maximum range of spatial dependency**. This parameter shouldn't exceed half of the extent.\n",
    "\n",
    "But that's not everything!\n",
    "\n",
    "We didn't use three other parameters:\n",
    "\n",
    "4. `direction`: it is a `float` in range [0, 360]. We set the direction of semivariogram:\n",
    "    * 0 or 180: is WE direction,\n",
    "    * 90 or 270 is NS direction,\n",
    "    * 45 or 225 is NW-SE direction,\n",
    "    * 135 or 315 is NE-SW direction.\n",
    "\n",
    "\n",
    "5. `tolerance`: it is a `float` in range [0, 1]. If we leave `tolerance` with default **1**, we will always get isotropic semivariogram. Other edge case is if we set `tolerance` to **0**, then points must be placed on a single line with the beginning in the origin of the coordinate system and the angle given by y axis and direction parameter. If tolerance is > 0 and < 1 then the bin is selected as an elliptical area with major axis pointed in the same direction as the line for 0 tolerance.\n",
    "    * The major axis size is `(tolerance * step_size)`,\n",
    "    * The minor axis size is `((1 - tolerance) * step_size)`,\n",
    "    * The baseline point is at a center of the ellipse.\n",
    "    \n",
    "    \n",
    "6. `method`: it is `str` with possible values:\n",
    "    - `t` or `triangle` for triangular neighbors selection which is fast and recommended for a big dataset,\n",
    "    - `e` or `ellipse` for elliptical neighbors selection which is accurate but slow, recommended for a small size datasets.\n",
    "    \n",
    "The best idea is to visualize it on a cartesian plane:"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "64ad5d92",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%% md\n"
    }
   },
   "source": [
    "<img src=\"imgs/dir_semi_tutorial_graphics.jpg\" alt=\"The visualization of directional variogram calculation\" style=\"max-width: 800px;\"/>"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "56b00cdd",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%% md\n"
    }
   },
   "source": [
    "* The top plane shows a unit circle that is the omnidirectional variogram (black circle). Within it we see two ellipses: one is bright-green and another is dark green.\n",
    "* The bottom plane also shows a unit circle and two ellipses. The brighter yellow, and darker purple ellipse.\n",
    "* The long arrows within both circles are radiuses of the omnidirectional variogram or **the semi-major axis** of a directional ellipse. It's length is controlled by the `step_size` parameter. The short arrows are present only in the **directional variograms** and they are **the semi-minor axes**. Their length is controlled by `tolerance` parameter and it is always:\n",
    "  - a fraction of `step_size`,\n",
    "  - **1**, in this case a semivariogram is omnidirectional,\n",
    "  - a value very close to 0 (but not 0) - in this case ellipse falls into a line.\n",
    "* The good idea is to set `tolerance` to 0.5 and then gradually make it smaller or larger (it depends on the spatial features)."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "5804f666",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%% md\n"
    }
   },
   "source": [
    "Now, when we understand how our parameters affect semivariogram bins range, we can start analysis. We will set `tolerance` to 0.2 in each case to better visualize the effects of a leading direction.\n",
    "\n",
    "### Case 1: W-E Direction"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 9,
   "id": "3a6ea200",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%%\n"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "BIN_RADIUS = 60000  # meters\n",
    "MAX_RANGE = 400000  # meters\n",
    "TOLERANCE = 0.2"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 10,
   "id": "8061065d",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%%\n"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "inp_arr = np.array(list(zip(gds['geometry'].x,\n",
    "                            gds['geometry'].y,\n",
    "                            gds[DATASET])))"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 12,
   "id": "60a5375c",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%%\n"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "\n",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 1200x600 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "we_variogram = build_experimental_variogram(\n",
    "    input_array=inp_arr,\n",
    "    step_size=BIN_RADIUS,\n",
    "    max_range=MAX_RANGE,\n",
    "    direction=0,\n",
    "    tolerance=TOLERANCE,\n",
    "    method='e'\n",
    ")\n",
    "\n",
    "we_variogram.plot(plot_semivariance=True)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "35e2def0",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%% md\n"
    }
   },
   "source": [
    "### Case 2: N-E Direction"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 13,
   "id": "d41edcd7",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%%\n"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "\n",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 1200x600 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "ne_variogram = build_experimental_variogram(\n",
    "    input_array=inp_arr,\n",
    "    step_size=BIN_RADIUS,\n",
    "    max_range=MAX_RANGE,\n",
    "    direction=90,\n",
    "    tolerance=TOLERANCE,\n",
    "    method='e'\n",
    ")\n",
    "\n",
    "ne_variogram.plot(plot_semivariance=True)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "155cd9e4",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%% md\n"
    }
   },
   "source": [
    "### Case 3: NW-SE Direction"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 16,
   "id": "8e9fcbac",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%%\n"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "\n",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 1200x600 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "nw_se_variogram = build_experimental_variogram(\n",
    "    input_array=inp_arr,\n",
    "    step_size=BIN_RADIUS,\n",
    "    max_range=MAX_RANGE,\n",
    "    direction=45,\n",
    "    tolerance=TOLERANCE,\n",
    "    method='e'\n",
    ")\n",
    "\n",
    "nw_se_variogram.plot(plot_semivariance=True)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "9e751fea",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%% md\n"
    }
   },
   "source": [
    "### Case 4: NE-SW Direction"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 17,
   "id": "77c3cc77",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%%\n"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "\n",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 1200x600 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "ne_sw_variogram = build_experimental_variogram(\n",
    "    input_array=inp_arr,\n",
    "    step_size=BIN_RADIUS,\n",
    "    max_range=MAX_RANGE,\n",
    "    direction=135,\n",
    "    tolerance=TOLERANCE,\n",
    "    method='e'\n",
    ")\n",
    "\n",
    "ne_sw_variogram.plot(plot_semivariance=True)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "bd879673",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%% md\n"
    }
   },
   "source": [
    "### Case 5: Isotropic Variogram"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 18,
   "id": "8ead8f69",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%%\n"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "\n",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 1200x600 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "iso_variogram = build_experimental_variogram(\n",
    "    input_array=inp_arr,\n",
    "    step_size=BIN_RADIUS,\n",
    "    max_range=MAX_RANGE\n",
    ")\n",
    "\n",
    "iso_variogram.plot()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "00f0d439",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%% md\n"
    }
   },
   "source": [
    "## 3) Compare semivariograms\n",
    "\n",
    "We have created a set of variograms. What did we observe?\n",
    "\n",
    "- The **NE-SW** variogram is very weak at describing a short-range variation (compare it to the map of air pollution from the beginning of the tutorial. Points in this direction are rather similar).\n",
    "- The **N-S** variogram seems to work well for a short range.\n",
    "- The **W-E** variogram catches too much variability, lags are too short for this direction.\n",
    "- The **NW-SE** variogram looks good, and shows approximately linear change of variability in a function of distance. It has the smallest variance from all variograms.\n",
    "\n",
    "We can visualize and compare all variograms at once, that we are sure that the y-axis is the same for every plot."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 19,
   "id": "c91fb4ca",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%%\n"
    }
   },
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "\n",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 2000x800 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "_lags = iso_variogram.lags\n",
    "_ns = ns_variogram.experimental_semivariances\n",
    "_we = we_variogram.experimental_semivariances\n",
    "_nw_se = nw_se_variogram.experimental_semivariances\n",
    "_ne_sw = ne_sw_variogram.experimental_semivariances\n",
    "_iso = iso_variogram.experimental_semivariances\n",
    "\n",
    "plt.figure(figsize=(20, 8))\n",
    "plt.plot(_lags, _iso, color='black')\n",
    "plt.plot(_lags, _ns, '--', color='#c2a5cf')\n",
    "plt.plot(_lags, _we, '--', color='#e7d4e8')\n",
    "plt.plot(_lags, _nw_se, '--', color='#5aae61')\n",
    "plt.plot(_lags, _ne_sw, '--', color='#1b7837')\n",
    "plt.title('Comparison of experimental semivariance models')\n",
    "plt.legend(['Isotropic',\n",
    "            'NS',\n",
    "            'WE',\n",
    "            'NW-SE',\n",
    "            'NE-SW'])\n",
    "plt.xlabel('Distance')\n",
    "plt.ylabel('Semivariance')\n",
    "plt.show()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "6e82a6e7",
   "metadata": {
    "pycharm": {
     "name": "#%% md\n"
    }
   },
   "source": [
    "What do you think about this comparison? Do you agree, that the **NW-SE** variogram is the best fit for a data?"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "6d4c36b1",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## 4) Bonus: Compare calculation times and results\n",
    "\n",
    "Let's compare calculation times and results from two methods of neighbors interpolation: `t` (triangular) and `e` (elliptical). We use for it **NW-SE** direction."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 20,
   "id": "b5a34f64",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "from datetime import datetime"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 28,
   "id": "0a351442",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "t0e = datetime.now()\n",
    "\n",
    "# Here elliptical\n",
    "\n",
    "nw_se_variogram_elliptical = build_experimental_variogram(\n",
    "    input_array=inp_arr,\n",
    "    step_size=BIN_RADIUS,\n",
    "    max_range=MAX_RANGE,\n",
    "    direction=45,\n",
    "    tolerance=TOLERANCE,\n",
    "    method='e'\n",
    ")\n",
    "\n",
    "tfin_e = (datetime.now() - t0e).total_seconds()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 29,
   "id": "a98e7ebd",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "t0t = datetime.now()\n",
    "\n",
    "# Here triangular\n",
    "\n",
    "nw_se_variogram_triangular = build_experimental_variogram(\n",
    "    input_array=inp_arr,\n",
    "    step_size=BIN_RADIUS,\n",
    "    max_range=MAX_RANGE,\n",
    "    direction=45,\n",
    "    tolerance=TOLERANCE,\n",
    "    method='t'\n",
    ")\n",
    "\n",
    "tfin_t = (datetime.now() - t0t).total_seconds()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 30,
   "id": "0b071f26",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
      "The triangular method is 1.3064327539647926 times faster than the elliptical selection.\n"
     ]
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "msg = f'The triangular method is {tfin_e / tfin_t} times faster than the elliptical selection.'\n",
    "\n",
    "print(msg)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "8a56a685",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "For this scenario the triangular method is 1.3x faster than the elliptical selection, but with the larger number of points and point pairs this difference will can be greater, and triangular selection is 5x faster for a big datasets.\n",
    "\n",
    "Are variograms different? Let's compare!"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 31,
   "id": "844366d7",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "\n",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 2000x800 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "_lags = iso_variogram.lags\n",
    "_nw_se_ell = nw_se_variogram_elliptical.experimental_semivariances\n",
    "_nw_se_tri = nw_se_variogram_triangular.experimental_semivariances\n",
    "\n",
    "plt.figure(figsize=(20, 8))\n",
    "plt.plot(_lags, _nw_se_ell)\n",
    "plt.plot(_lags, _nw_se_tri)\n",
    "plt.title('Comparison of experimental semivariance models for NW-SE direction.')\n",
    "plt.legend(['Elliptical selection', 'Triangular selection'])\n",
    "plt.xlabel('Distance')\n",
    "plt.ylabel('Semivariance')\n",
    "plt.show()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "cdeb2c64",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "The general shape is the same but variance of a semivariogram from a triangular selection is lower; it is harder to distinguish the covariance between neighboring points, and it could be dangerously close to the nugget effect. You should consider this (especially) in automatic calculations to avoid a strange results or models that are not better than a simple IDW technique.\n",
    "\n",
    "But semivariogram for elliptical selection can have a different parameters than for the triangular selection. If you choose a different step size and tolerance, the shape of semivariogram may change and it could better describe dissimilarities."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "30faec20",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "---"
   ]
  }
 ],
